latestIgtvVideos.caption:
Wooden play gyms for newborns have a lot of advantages

Babies are attracted to contrasting colors and some elements hung from a play gym are great for their visual development and to learn cause and effect

A wooden play gym on a mat is a good idea for babies to give them some floor time to concentrate

Having the baby reach, grasp, turn, and kick for hanging items can aid in hand-eye coordination and fine and gross motor skills

In a Montessori setting we usually use a simple baby play gym made from wood

I personally loved the quality of the wooden play gym from @reorigin.in as it’s light weight, sturdy, easy to assemble and painted using non-toxic paints

I can’t wait for my niece/nephew to use this once she/he is here :)

You can use the code ANKITA5 if you happen to shop from their website, they have a beautiful collection of wooden toys
.
.
.
.
.
.
#montessorifrombirth #montessoritoddler #montessoriano #montessorikids #montessoriactivities #montessoriinspired #montessorimaterials #montessorimethod #wherelearningmeetsplay #montessoriteacher  #earlychildhoodlearning #montessoriplay #earlyyearsteacher #montessoryathome #playingislearning #childledlearning #montessoritoys #playmatters #playbased

Scissors can be offered to children around 18 months of age!

Observation will help us understand if the child is ready or not. Baby AS started using scissors around 21 months of age, as she showed real interest and her motor skills were developed as well

At 2 years she was cutting paper, parcels, even tried to cut my hair 🙈, that was the level of interest she had in cutting work

She has been using regular scissors for a while now. We have a scissor accessible to her at all times on her art shelf and she works with them almost everyday

That’s the beauty of montessori, we trust the child, follow the child’s interest and prepare the environment

We will be talking scissor progression and the exploration possibilities in the Art Workshop :)

Really excited to share all about the scissor work we’ve been doing with you all 🤗

(The second batch is happening on the 13th of Feb at 3 pm. Limited seats available)
.
.
.
.
.
.

For a toddler, traveling is a beautiful experience. And a trip to nani house is truly special

I had traveled with baby AS in February last year  when she was about 16 months old and it was a very difficult trip

She had a lot of separation anxiety and was very stressed about the change in environment and caregivers. She used to talk a lot normally but she just shut herself up and became quiet. So, I cut my trip short and came back to bangalore to familiar surroundings so ease her stress. Her emotional well-being has always been our top priority

This time at 25 months, the trip was very different. She knew she’s going to meet her other family and her 6 year old cousin and was very excited about it 

The 3 hour flight was a cakewalk as she manages to sleep in moving vehicles easily

I didn’t have to worry about in flight entertainment and only carried some art supplies and one or two materials

We spent a lot of time looking at the clouds and talking about the flying experience. The language development was immense as she now uses words like aircraft, check-in, airbus and what not!

At nani house (Guwahati, Assam), she had a blast. From lighting candles in the church on Christmas to elephant rides and boating, from bonding with the family to independently playing with her sister, and watching the ducks from the balcony all day, it was bliss

My brother took over chores like bath time and morning walks and he entertained her all day long, which was awesome :)

Cannot wait to travel again in a few months :)
.
.
.
.
.
.
#traveling #travelblogger #travelblog #assamtourism #guwahati #northeastindia #covidtravel #toddlertravel #toddlertravels #familyholidays #familyvacay #bangaloremommyblogger #indianmomblogger #assamtourism #assamdiaries #travelexperience 
Music: King
Musician: Jeff Kaale

Color sorting activity for toddlers!

After the child has had some experience with colors via environmental exploration the child might show an interest in pairing colors and sorting them (around 18 months or later)

This might happen irrespective of the child knowing the color names because color is a sensory concept (the sense of sight)

I remember once we were cleaning up and Baby AS took away all the items of orange color and collected them in a basket - that’s when I noticed that she was interested in sorting.She had already worked on pairing objects at that time.

Following her lead we offered her the crochet balls and matching bowls (@playhun_official)

We didn’t do any formal presentation or anything. She independently explored and worked with this material for the entire week 

Sometimes she matches the crochet balls to each other, other times she’s matching the balls to the corresponding bowls and sometimes she’s also nesting the crochet bowls , other times she’s just counting the balls (upto 10)

She’s tried using tongs with this material to practice transferring too and really enjoyed it

This is not exactly a Montessori Material but it’s open-ended and there are many possibilities of exploration which I find really interesting

You can check out @playhun_official for this material and a lot more :)

P.S - Formal presentations on colours - colour names, pairing and grading are offered in Montessori Houses of Children anytime between 2.5 to 3 years. Please don’t rush to do color names with the child formally. They need to experience colours in their environment, in nature and the colour names can offered with usual objects during our conversations or while reading (We don’t need to quiz them or force them to learn)
They have an absorbent mind and they’ll grasp it if our environment is rich enough for them

Also, why Baby AS is explaining the activity is because she was showing me how to work with it and so she was explaining it like I would :)
.
.
.
.
.
.
#montessorimethod #montessoriteacher #earlychildhoodlearning #montessoriplay #earlyyearsteacher #montessoryathome #playingislearning #childledlearning #montessoritoys

From decorating the Christmas tree, baking a cake to singing songs there are a ton of ways to help the child immerse themselves in Christmas celebrations.

We have been doing some of the above. Sharing some Winter/Christmas shelf and art work for toddlers - 

1. Music Box - I cannot begin to share how wonderful it is to use a music box. It has helped in developing patience and the ability to sit and listen and it’s just magical

2. Story Basket - Just a book and some props can create magic together

3. Magnetism - Working with Christmas bells and a magnetic and to experience attraction is a great activity. Also we end up singing almost everytime we are working with this material

4. Playdough tray - some dough, a cookie cutter, a pinecone and some embellishments can be a lot of fun to explore

5. Music Basket - Red and Green play scarves, bells, tambourine :)

6. Sticker Activity - Because why not :)

Are you doing any Christmassy activities ? Please share, would love to know
.
.
.
.
.
.
#christmasmood #christmasforkids #toddlerchristmas #christmasactivities #christmasactivitiesforkids #christmasactivity #indianmomblogger #christmasathome #montessorieducation #montessoriactivity #montessoritoddler #montessoriactivities @toyroomtoys @doughremom @picky_wood #considermontessori #toddleractivities

Dancing !

Yes you heard me right!

There is nothing and I mean NOTHING that a song and a dance can’t fix in our home and I rely on being silly to get through most things

It’s one of the ways we connect after we’ve gone through a big emotion

Also, this is what we are mostly doing in our playroom—

Getting down to her level,
Being silly,
Dancing and prancing,
And going crazy

Baby AS is 20 months old here

What’s your favourite way of connecting with your child ?
.
.
.
.
.
.
.

This year our favourite number is Jingle Bell Rock by Bobby Helms!

“It should be evident when you enter a child’s space, that it is a child’s space” - These words by my mentor keep ringing in my ears (from time I did my Montessori Diploma Course)

And then there is this quote by Maria Montessori - “The first aim of the prepared environment is, as far as it is possible, to render the growing child independent of the adult”

The environment we prepare for our child keeps changing depending on the need of the child at any given stage.

Sharing some pointers on this topic -

1. Just placing a Dustan brush at a child’s height isn’t enough. It’s better to place them separately as long toddlers would take time to learn how to place them back as a set. Till then, they can hang it on separate hooks without depending on an adult

2. Color-coding is a good idea as the child understand that the materials belong together

3. Think local - We used a child-sized chair at the entrance but it didn’t work well, so we just got a mooda and it works really well as it’s quite low

4. Towels on hooks don’t just promote independence but also helps in motor skill development

5. A Chowki that the child can carry around works really well. We also use the sensory table as it’s large and great for artwork (do what works for your child)

6. Floor Beds are just amazing. We have a small bed for reading/relaxing and a bigger one for sleeping at night

There are many more ideas of a prepared environment. If you need any assistance on the same, feel free to DM/book a consultation or inquire about the Montessori at home program!
.
.
.
.
.
.
#montessoriathome #montessorihome #montessoritoddler #montessoritoddlerspaces #toddlerlife #toddler #toddlerpracticallife #toddlersofinstagram #montessori #montessorihomeschooling #montessoriactivities #montessorimaterials #homeschoolpreschool #homeschooling #homeschoollife #preparedenvironment #childsroom #montessoriroom #playroomideas #indianmommy 
Music: Zurna
Musician: Sapajou

If your child is going to be introduced to the sounds of the letters via the method of phonetics or phonics, you can choose to skip the traditional ABCD style of learning English.

When I was working at Head Start Montessori Bangalore, I realised that children who haven’t seen the letters before, just tend to pick up the phonetics sounds at 2.5 to 3 years seamlessly and have no confusion associating the sounds to the respective letters.

I’ve also witnessed the insta trend and the pressure on children to memorise and recognise ABCD by a certain age, hence I am sharing, that in my experience, we don’t need to do that at all - provided we will be following the method of phonics or phonetics to help them learn the sounds in English language.

So parents, don’t feel the pressure, just trust the child and the method :)

In a Montessori house of children we introduce sounds via oral phonetic activities.

After the child has participated in a few preparatory activities in sound recognition, we begin to offer sand paper letters.

We believe that children need help - to first become conscious of the sounds of the spoken language. Eventually the child will acquire the capacity to graphically express himself - which is nothing but writing.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.

Music: Sunny
Musician: Ilya Truhanov

Winter is here and it’s a good time to set-up a snowy themed sensory play!

The inspiration arrived in the form of polar footprints material by @sensoryplayco (Discount code ANKITA15)

Each stone shows a footprint on one side and its owner on the other side! They are extremely durable! They also come with a card for each animal which can be used in ways more than one

Other materials -

-We’ve been collecting the leftovers from making neer dosa batter. Chilled it and used it for snow effect

-Polar bears and penguins are from amazon

Disclaimer - it’s always better to have them experience real animals before doing set-ups or even showing them cards. But I felt like she has experienced all the seasons and has a good understanding of animals so went ahead and set-up this theme.

Cannot wait to take her to snow-capped mountains and possibly, some day, show her the real polar animals :)
.
.
.
.
.
.
.

latestPosts.caption:
Biggest bonding tip : Have that one special song that your child can sing to your baby during pregnancy and after birth, babies remember songs that are sing to them in womb :)

My 5 year old calls our baby “Shortcake” and talks to my belly every chance she gets. 

Not because I forced it, but because when children feel included, they naturally want to be part of the story.

What I’m seeing work:
The families where older children are genuinely excited are actually part of bringing their sibling home.

Children who help prepare for baby have way fewer adjustment issues later and

Sibling bonds that start during pregnancy are stronger and last longer

More ideas that work:

-Have them help fold tiny baby clothes (builds so much excitement)
-Create a big sibling scrapbook together
-Have them draw pictures - we are making some black and white cards for the first weeks :)
-Practice gentle belly touches
-Let them help pack the hospital bag
-Take them to see baby on ultrasound - makes baby feel real to them

Watching my daughter light up when she feels Shortcake move? That’s not just cute - that’s bonding happening in real time.

Would love to hear suggestions from mamas who are raising more than one child :)
.
.
.
.
#SiblingBonding #PregnancyTips #EarlyChildhood #PositiveParenting #SiblingPrep #PregnancyHacks #FamilyBonding #ParentingTips #EvidenceBasedParenting #PregnancyJourney #BigSibling

Music: Dear Autumn
Musician: @iksonmusic

After co-sleeping for 5 years, we moved Aish to her own bed. She settled in 3 days. There were small tears, but nothing that she couldn’t handle with our help.

Sleep is a very personal thing, works differently for each family.

We weren’t ready at 2 but we were ready at 5. A part of me wishes we had done this earlier, but it doesn’t matter, as long as it’s done. She feels so independent it is beautiful. 

Every child needs a different level of support and I feel if we slow down and follow their lead, it is possible.

While it is not possible to share the method here as it took alignment of many areas such as daily routine, giving her a lot of control back during the day, working on her on independence level during the day , outdoor time, bedtime routine, working on our own regulation and so on…

I am excited to invite you to our 3 day parenting program called R.A.I.S.E which gives you a method to the madness. Think of it like an M.B.A in parenting , a system for all the stuff that goes on from birth to 7 years. It is the early childhood development course that you wish your parents had taken :)

If you need more info - please check my highlights, or comment “Raise” and I will send you the link to read more about it and register. (For July & August batches)

Parenting has never been harder, but so much parenting support has never been available either :) this is your chance to become the parent your child deserves :)
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
#parentingcoach #parentingprograms #earlychildhood #earlychildhooddevelopment

latestPosts.caption:
Our babies brought us together, but our friendship keeps us connected 💕 

So grateful for this village that keeps us sane through all the beautiful chaos of motherhood.

There’s something magical about friends who get it - the hard days and nights, the endless giggles, the breakdowns and the beautiful mess

This shoot with @loveandmemoriesofficial captured more than just my bump - it captured the love that surrounds this little one already.

To anyone reading this: find your village, cherish your village, and don’t forget to document these sweet moments with the people who make this journey so much more beautiful ✨

My Outfit : @label_kalon 
Venue @itcgardenia 
Shot by @loveandmemoriesofficial 
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
#village #pregnancyshoot #friendshipgoals #momtribe #grateful #babylove #thirdtrimester #loveandmemories

latestPosts.caption:
Being your child’s safe haven is the secret to raising emotionally secure children 🌟

When children feel truly seen, heard, and unconditionally accepted, they develop into confident, compassionate, and emotionally intelligent adults.

Start with these gentle shifts:

-Listen without rushing to fix
-Validate their big feelings (even the messy ones)
-Create space for expression, not suppression
-Set loving boundaries that feel safe, not scary

Your calm energy becomes their inner peace ✨
Your steady support becomes their unshakeable confidence 💪

Save this for those challenging parenting moments when you need the reminder 📌
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
#EmotionallySecureKids #GentleParenting #ConsciousParenting #ParentingTips #RaisingConfidentKids

Pregnancy changed everything, including my relationship with my skin. The products I once loved suddenly felt too harsh, too uncertain.

I found myself reading every label, questioning every ingredient, because it wasn’t just about me anymore. 

That’s when I found @orimiiskincare - a brand that truly understands this phase. Their formulas are gentle, made without harsh actives, and created to be worry-free for both mama and baby 💛

And now, I feel at ease with my skincare. Because taking care of myself should feel as safe and nurturing as taking care of my baby 👶💛

latestPosts.caption:
The truth about raising kind kids that no parenting book tells you 👇

Most parents think kindness is taught through lectures and consequences. But science shows us something completely different.

Your child’s brain between ages 3-7 is literally wiring itself based on what they witness daily. Every interaction you have becomes their internal blueprint for how to treat others.

Here’s what’s really happening:
• When you’re patient with a slow cashier → they learn empathy
• When you help a neighbor without being asked → they learn generosity• When you speak kindly about difficult people → they learn compassion
• When you admit your mistakes gracefully → they learn humility

The game-changer? Children don’t copy what we SAY about kindness - they copy what we DO.

That moment when you’re frustrated and choose gentleness anyway? Your child just learned more about kindness than any storybook could teach.

Try this week:
✨ Narrate your kind choices: “I’m choosing to be patient because everyone has hard days”
✨ Include them in kind acts: let them help you bake cookies for a sick friend
✨ Model self-compassion: show them how to speak kindly to yourself when you make mistakes

Remember: You’re not just raising a child - you’re raising the adult they’ll become. The kindness you model today ripples into their relationships, their parenting, and their impact on the world.

What’s one way you modeled kindness today? 
.
.
.
.
.
.
#KindnessIsContagious #ParentingTips #RaisingKindKids #PositiveParenting #MontessoriParenting #ParentingCoach #EarlyChildhood #ModelingBehavior

@Nilsbergman research is life changing. We will see babies and skin to skin in a different light after watching this.

I wish every expecting parent, and every caregiver watches this video :)

DM me “link” for the complete video and share this with a mama to be/ papa to be :)
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
#PregnancyEducation #ExpectingParents #PregnancyTips #NewParents #PregnancyJourney​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

✨ Your pregnancy journey, your timeline 

There’s no “right” time to share your beautiful news - only the time that feels right for YOU. Whether you’re bursting to tell the world at 4 weeks or prefer to wait until after your first trimester, trust your instincts.

If you suspect someone might be expecting, give them the gift of space and privacy. Let them share their joy when they’re ready. Sometimes the most loving thing we can do is simply wait with patience and understanding.

To all the expecting parents reading this: Share when it feels authentic to you.

What matters isn’t when you announce - it’s that you feel supported and empowered in whatever choice you make. 💕

Save this post to share with someone who needs this reminder :)

Did you know - This time I only told my family , friends much much after 12 weeks and others only around 6 months :)
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
#PregnancyJourney #ExpectingParents #PregnancySupport #MomToBe #PregnancyWisdom #BumpLife​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​
